objdescid.compdate: c. 1825-26This is one of two water colors commissioned by Sir Thomas Lawrence near the end of Blake's life (see the Note on Provenance). The other water color commissioned by Lawrence is *The Wise and Foolish Virgins*, Butlin 481. According to Alexander Gilchrist, *Life of William Blake* (London and Cambridge: Macmillan and Co., 1863) 1:357, these were among "the last drawings executed, or at least finished by Blake. ...Sir Thomas gave fifteen guineas apiece for these designs of Blake's."

objinfo.medium: water color, Chinese white, and shell goldThe inscription, lower right, is scratched into the water color.

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.
provenance.note: Commissioned from Blake by Thomas Lawrence c. 1825-26 for £15.15s. (see the Note on Composition Date, above); sold from Lawrence's collection, Christie's, 21 May 1830, lot 235 (£4.6s. to "Kennedy," probably a dealer); John Clark Strange by 1863; Edward Burnett Tylor; his niece, Mrs. Sydney Morse, probably by inheritance in 1917; sold Christie's, 26 July 1929, lot 16 (£1942.10s. to the dealer P. & D. Colnaghi); sold 18 March 1930 to Lessing J. Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C., in 1943.

repository.addressline: Constitution Avenue NW, between 3rd and 9th Streets
Mailing Address: 2000B South Club Drive, Landover, Maryland 20785

desc.objtitle: The Vision of Queen Katharine, Object 1 (Butlin 549.1)

objnote.p: The verso is inscribed by John Clark Strange, "Bought at the T Lawrence Sale Lot 137 5/5/0 JCS." This note is wrong about the lot number in the Thomas Lawrence sale in 1830 (see the Note on Provenance). Butlin 549 comments that "the increase in the price ... suggests that [the dealer] Kennedy may have bought [the work] on his own account, not on commission for Strange, who otherwise does not seem to have been active as a purchaser of Blakes until 1853." This work is a more highly-finished replica, with several variations, of Butlin 548, The Vision of Queen Katharine, in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three large figures, two female and one male, and at least twenty-six smaller figures occupy the space of the composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Act 4, Scene 2 of Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. The central female figure of Queen Katharine reclines on a bed or couch with legs together at left but with her torso raised and facing forward. She has long hair and wears a gown and veil. Both arms are bent and raised just above the horizontal with palms facing up. Her head and eyes are also raised, perhaps to better see the visionary activity above her. Queen Katharine is the wife of King Henry VIII who wishes to divorce her (as she has not born a male heir) and marry Anne Boleyn. Katharine becomes ill, and it is during her sickness in which The Vision occurs. The bed or couch on which she sits has arms on both sides and is covered in what appears to be a patterned fabric decorated with Gothic arches forming niches with human figures vaguely suggested within them. A pillow is partially visible at right and drapery or sheets cover the seat and closest edge of the piece of furniture. In front of the bed in both lower corners of the composition, the other two large figures sit facing each other on straight-backed chairs that are embellished with patterns similar to the bed or couch. Both figures have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The figure in the right corner is a gowned female with long hair who rests her elbow on a soft object of some sort (perhaps a pillow?) on the table at her right. This is probably Patience, a servant to the queen. The male figure at left has white hair and a long beard; he is also gowned. This is probably Griffith, the queen's usher. He rests his elbow on a similar table behind him and turns his head to face forward. In his right hand, which is by his side, he holds a scroll and pen or quill. The floor, which may be a carpet or rug, between these two figures is decorated with arch-like patterns evocative of Gothic art similar to that of the couch or bed as well as the chairs on either side. The twenty-six other smaller figures in the scene fly around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image. They fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Just above the center of the lower margin, the lowest of these figures faces forward and right and appears to stand on tiptoe on the floor or hover just above it. She is gowned and female with short (or perhaps coiffed) hair. Her left leg is bent and her right is extended backward. With her right hand, she holds (and perhaps plays) a lyre and with her left arm, which is extended, she holds the hand of the figure above her at right, who flies upward and faces away and to the right. This figure is also a gowned female who holds a trumpet or horn in her raised right hand. Above and to the right of this figure, a third gowned female figure, who has a circle of light around her head and may wear a crown or garland, flies facing forward and slightly right as an infant or putto flies beside her at left facing away. The female figure plays a harp with both hands. Above and to the left of this pair, a second pair of figures flies upward and to the left. The figure at right is a gowned female figure who faces away and turns her head to the left. She raises both arms vertically and holds one or more circular objects in her hand (perhaps flower blossoms?). The lower figure at right, who has long hair and thus may be a female(?) child, raises one arm upward and may hold a similar round object. Immediately to the left of this figure, the seventh figure in this group, who has coiffed hair, a crown/garland, and a gown, faces away but bends to the left with arms extended and spread. In her raised right hand, she holds a serpentine object (perhaps a horn or shell?) and with her lowered left, the right side of a garland or crown. Together with another figure at left who holds the other side of the crown, she may be preparing to crown Queen Katharine below. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2). A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The first of these figures near the lower right portion of the circle flies right and extends her left arm to hold the other side of the laurel crown over the head of Queen Katharine. In her right hand, she holds and perhaps plays a lyre. She wears a crown and a gown that exposes her breasts and her long hair streams behind her at left. Directly below her right arm, a small nude infant or putto faces away and flies up and to the right. Directly above this pair at right, two small nude figures face forward and fly upward with arms raised overhead and may hold similar small round objects, perhaps blossoms(?). A fifth figure, whose body is twisted to the left, flies to the left directly above this pair, and she wears a long gown and extends both arms forward to hold and play a lyre. The figure flying at her left wears a gown that exposes her breasts. Her body is horizontal, and she faces forward but turns her head slightly right. Her mouth may be open. She raises both arms horizontally and may wear a necklace. Below the extended left arm of this figure, a seventh figure who is upside down and twisted to the right flies downward and right. With both arms bent and raised, she plays two trumpets or horns. Directly below this figure, the final figure in this circle flies to the right with her left arm raised horizontally and her right extended upward near the above figure. She wears a gown and a crown or garland above short hair. Above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a cluster of five figures fly or hover at right. The two lower figures face forward and turn their head to look up in opposite directions, and both hold harps or lyres. A third figure above this pair faces forward and leans to the left. She wears a gown and a crown over long hair. In her left arm she holds and plays a lute; she raised her bent right arm at 135 degrees, perhaps to reach for one of the small round objects floating to her left. To the right of this figure, a gowned figure who bends forward and faces left holds a (wicker?) basket atop her head with both arms. A second gowned figure flying above her at left faces forward but bends left to reach into the basket with her right arm. Her left arm is raised vertically. Above this cluster of figures at left, two gowned figures who face away fly or hover near the upper margin of the design. They bend sharply to the left and extend their arms vertically and hold (and play) instruments, a lyre at right and a tambourine at left. Above the heads of these figures, traces of the gowns of three additional figures are visible emerging from the upper margin, suggesting additional figures who have flown upward out of the scene. A final group of four figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. Directly below and left of the tambourine player at top, a gowned female figure flies or hovers facing forward and left with both arms extended horizontally, palms facing up. She has long hair and may wear a crown or garland. Her mouth may be open. Forming the left side of the circle, a gowned female figure who faces forward flies upside down with her body twisted to the right. Both of her arm are raised overhead to hold or take flowers(?) from the (wicker?) basket carried on the head of the gowned female figure to her right who also flies to the right and wears a gown. This figure holds her basket with both arms bent overhead and her mouth may be open. To her right, the fourth figure flies right, facing away, with arms extended horizontally. With her right hand, she appears to reach for or drop small objects, perhaps fruit or blossoms(?). Visible against each side margin near the top of the composition, two piers or pillars with vaguely Corinthian capitals support (what is likely) a pointed arch, though the arch itself is obscured. Beams of light extend outward from the upper middle of the composition, often terminating in dark, spiky points that form concentric bands, particularly on the left side of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Three large figures and at least twenty-six smaller figures occupy the space of the composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Act 4, Scene 2 of Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. The central female figure of Queen Katharine reclines or sits on a bed or couch with legs together (and right leg bent) at left but with her torso raised and facing forward. She has long hair and wears a gown and veil. Both arms are bent and raised just above the horizontal with palms facing up. Her head and eyes are also raised, perhaps to better see the visionary activity above her. Queen Katharine is the wife of King Henry VIII who wishes to divorce her (as she has not born a male heir) and marry Anne Boleyn. Katharine becomes ill, and it is during her sickness in which The Vision occurs.

The bed or couch on which Queen Katharine, the central figure, sits has large arms on either side. Its fabric is patterned with Gothic arches that resemble the arch in the upper part of the scene. The arches above the queen's legs and on the arms of the couch form niches containing the outlines of standing human figures, facing forward. A pillow is visible at right and drapery or sheets cover the seat and fall over the front edge of the furniture.
The arches above the queen's legs on the decorated cloth covering her couch form niches containing pictures of standing human figures, facing forward.

In front of the bed in both lower corners of the composition, the other two large figures sit facing each other on straight-backed chairs. Both figures have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The figure in the right corner is a gowned female with long hair who rests her right elbow on a pillow with a tassel lower left on the table at her right, and she bends her right arm upward to rest her head on her hand. This is probably Patience, a servant to the queen. Her left arm is at her side with her left hand near her knee. Her left foot on which she wears a shoe is visible beneath the hem of her gown.

In the lower right corner, a gowned female figure sits in a straight-backed chair that is embellished with arch-like patterns evocative of Gothic art similar to the bed or couch. Facing left, she rests her right elbow on a pillow with a tassel lower left on a table at her right.

In front of the bed in both lower corners of the composition, the other two large figures sit facing each other on straight-backed chairs. Both figures have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The male figure at left has white hair, a mustache, and a long beard; he is also gowned. Bending forward, he rests his left elbow on a table behind him and turns his head to face forward with his head on his hand. This is probably Griffith, the queen's usher. In his right hand, which is by his side, he holds a scroll and pen or quill. His right leg is extended forward, and his right foot on which he wears a shoe is visible beneath the hem of his gown.

In the lower left corner, a gowned male figure sits in a straight-backed chair that is embellished with arch-like patterns evocative of Gothic art similar to the bed or couch and floor below. He faces right and rests his right elbow on a table at his left. In his right hand he holds a scroll and a quill or pen by his side.

The floor, which may be a carpet or rug, between these two figures is decorated with arch-like patterns evocative of Gothic art similar to that of the couch or bed as well as the chairs on either side.

Twenty-six other smaller figures in the scene fly around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body atop of plume of clouds in the lower half of the image. Just above the center of the lower margin, the lowest of these figures faces forward and right and appears to stand on tiptoe on the floor or hover just above it. She is gowned and female with short (or perhaps coiffed) hair. Her left leg is bent and her right is extended backward. With her right hand, she holds (and perhaps plays) a lyre and with her left arm, which is extended, she holds the hand of the figure above her at right, toward whom she may also look with head up.

Twenty-six smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. The second figure right of center flies upward and to the right with her legs together and extended backward. She has hair coiffed in a bun and wears a gown. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and she holds a horn or trumpet; her left is at her side and with her left hand holds the hand of the figure below her. She faces away but turns her head up and to the right.

Twenty-six smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Near the right margin, a third gowned female figure, who has a circle with beams of light around her head and may wear a crown or have short hair, flies facing forward and slightly right as an infant or putto flies beside her at left. The female figure plays a harp with both hands. Her legs are extended together and slightly bent.

Twenty-six smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Directly right of Queen Katharine's left hand, a third gowned female figure flies facing forward and slightly left as a nude infant or putto flies beside her at left. The child faces away and is seen from behind. Its hair is short, its leg are bent, and both bent arms are raised vertically.

Twenty-six smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Above the harp-playing figure near the right margin, another pair of figures flies upward and to the left. The figure at right is a gowned female figure who faces away and turns her head up and to the left. She has coiffed hair. She raises both arms vertically and holds one or more circular objects in her hand (perhaps blossoms?). Her legs are together and extended downward.

Twenty-six smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Above the harp-playing figure near the right margin, another pair of figures fly up and to the left. The child at left faces forward but turns her head to look right, perhaps at the figure above her at right. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her right arm is extended vertically and her left is at her side. With both hands, she may reach for small circular objects, perhaps blossoms(?). Her legs are extended and together, knees bent slightly.

Twenty-six smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Immediately to the left of the top pair of figures, the seventh figure in this group, who has short hair, a crown/garland, and a gown, faces away but bends to the left with arms extended and spread. Her head is twisted to face forward and down, perhaps to look toward Queen Katharine below. In her raised right hand, she holds a serpentine object (perhaps a horn or shell?) and with her lowered left, the right side of a garland or crown. Together with another figure at left who holds the other side of the crown, she may be preparing to crown Queen Katharine below. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2). Her legs are extended downward with her left leg bent at the knee.

The seven smaller figures who form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body hold and/or play a variety of objects and instruments. The lowest figure holds a lyre in her right hand. The figure above her at right holds a trumpet or horn, and the rightmost figure above her holds and plays a harp. The highest figure in this group holds a serpentine object (perhaps a horn or shell?) in her raised right hand and a laurel crown in her lowered left hand.
Several figures in the lowest group of smaller figures reach for or hold small circular objects that may be flower blossoms(?).

The seven small figures who form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body fly atop a single plume of clouds that appears to rise from the ground below the lowest figure or, alternatively, originate with this figure herself.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The first of these figures near the lower right portion of the circle flies right and extends her left arm to hold the other side of the laurel crown over the head of Queen Katharine. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2). In her right hand, she holds and perhaps plays a lyre. She wears a crown and a gown that exposes her breasts and her long hair streams behind her at left.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Directly below the right arm of the first figure, a small nude infant or putto faces away and flies up and to the right. He has short hair and extends his right arm vertically. His legs are extended backward with the left leg bent.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Directly above the first female figure holding the laurel crown, two small nude figures with short hair face forward and fly upward with arms raised overhead and may hold similar small round objects, perhaps blossoms(?). The figure at right faces slightly right, but twists to look left, and bends backward with legs extended backward and together.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Directly above the first female figure holding the laurel crown, two small nude figures with short hair face forward and fly upward with arms raised overhead and may hold similar small round objects, perhaps blossoms(?). The figure at left extends its legs backward, and his mouth may be open.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Above the pair of children, a fifth figure, whose body is twisted to the left, flies to the left. She wears a long gown and extends both arms forward to hold and play a lyre. She appears to look toward the figure flying at her left. Both legs are extended downward with her right leg bent backward.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The sixth figure who flies at the top of the circle facing left and forward wears a gown that exposes her breasts. Her body is horizontal, but she turns her head slightly right. Her hair is long and her mouth may be open. She raises both arms horizontally and may reach for or hold a small circular object, perhaps a blossom(?), with her left hand. She may wear a necklace. Her legs are together and extended to the right.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Forming the left upper curve of the circle, a seventh figure who is upside down and twisted to the right flies downward and right. She has coiffed hair and wears a gown. With both arms bent and raised, she plays two trumpets or horns.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Forming the lower left bend in the circle, the final figure flies to the right with her left arm raised horizontally and her right extended upward near the above figure where she may reach for a small circular object, perhaps a blossom(?). She wears a gown (which may expose her breasts) and a crown or garland above short hair. Her head is turned to face slightly left and her mouth may be open. Her legs are together and extended behind and above her.

The eight smaller figures who form a complete circle above and to the left of Queen Katharine hold and/or play a variety of objects and instruments. The lowest figure at right holds a lyre in her right hand and, in her left hand, a laurel crown, also held by the figure at her right. The fourth figure near the upper right bend in the circle holds a lyre, while the seventh figure on the upper left side holds and plays two horns or trumpets.

Four of the eight smaller figures who form a complete circle above and to the left Queen Katharine may hold and/or reach for small circular objects that resemble flower blossoms. The pair of children at right may hold them above their heads, the top central figure may reach for them with her extended left arm, and the figure lower left may reach for these with her right arm.
The eight smaller figures who form a complete circle above and to the left of Queen Katharine fly atop a ring of clouds that connects with the larger plume of clouds on the right side of the picture.

Above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a cluster of five figures fly or hover at right. The two lower figures, visible only from the waist up, face forward and turn their head to look up in opposite directions, and both hold harps or lyres. They appear to be nude. The figure at right looks up and right; she(?) may have long hair and appears to extend her bent left arm to the left, likely to hold or play the harp.

Above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a cluster of five figures fly or hover at right. The two lower figures, visible only from the waist up, face forward and turn their head to look up in opposite directions, and both hold harps or lyres. They appear to be nude. The figure at left looks up and left (perhaps toward the figure above her); she may have long (or coiffed) hair. With both arms bent upward, she holds and plays a lyre at left.

Above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a cluster of five figures fly or hover at right. A third figure above this pair faces forward and leans to the left with her head up. She wears a gown and a crown over long hair. In her left arm she holds and plays a lute; she raised her bent right arm at 135 degrees, perhaps to reach for one of the small round objects floating to her left (which may be blossoms?). Her legs are extended downward and together.

Above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a cluster of five figures fly or hover at right. To the right of the lute-playing figure, a gowned figure who faces away but twists to the left holds a (wicker?) basket atop her head with both arms. She turns her head down and may have coiffed hair. Her legs are extended backward.

>Above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a cluster of five figures fly or hover at right. The rightmost figure in the group is a gowned female figure with long hair who faces forward but bends left to reach with her right arm into the basket carried on the head of the figure below her at left. Her left arm is raised vertically, and she may reach for a small circular object above, perhaps a blossom(?).

Three figures in the group of five figures flying or hovering between and to the right of the two circular groups of figures hold instruments. The two lowest figures hold harps or lyres and the figure immediately above them holds a lute in her bent left arm.
The group of five figures near the right side of the composition fly atop clouds that extend from the larger plume of clouds originating in the lower center of the picture.

Just below the upper margin of the design on the right, two gowned figures who face away fly or hover. They bend sharply to the left and extend their arms vertically and hold (and play) instruments. The figure at right holds a harp with her left hand and plays with her right. Her hair appears to be in a bun, and she turns her head to face left, perhaps to look toward her companion at left. Her right leg is bent backward.

Just below the upper margin of the design on the right, two gowned figures who face away fly or hover. They bend sharply to the left and extend their arms vertically and hold (and play) instruments. The figure at left has short hair or wears it coiffed. She twists her head up to face up and holds a tambourine in her right hand and plays the instruments with her left. One of her legs is extended downward and the other at a right angle backward.

Above the heads of the two figures closest to the top of the design, traces of the gowns of three additional figures are visible emerging diagonally rightward from the upper margin. These suggest additional figures who have flown upward out of the scene.

A cloud is visible beneath the figure flying or hovering closest to the top right corner of the composition. This cloud connects with the larger plume of clouds extending upward from the lower center of the picture.

A final group of four figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. Directly below and left of the tambourine player near the top margin, a gowned female figure flies or hovers facing forward and left with both arms extended horizontally, palms facing up. She may touch the foot of the figure to her left with her extended right hand. She has long hair and may wear a crown or garland. Her mouth may be open. Her legs are together and extended backward.

A final group of four smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. Forming the left side of the circle, a gowned female figure who faces forward flies or hovers upside down with her body twisted to the right. She appears to have short hair. Both of her arms are raised overhead (with her left arm bent) to hold or take flowers(?) from the (wicker?) basket carried on the head of the gowned female figure to her right. Her legs are extended upward and her left appears to be bent.

A final group of four smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. The third figure who flies right or hovers at the bottom edge of the circle holds a (wicker?) basket full of fruit or flowers(?) atop her head with both arms bent upward. She faces forward but turns her head slightly left, perhaps to look toward the figure flying to her left. Her mouth may be open. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her body is horizontal and her legs are together and extended backward.

A final group of four smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. In the lower right of the circle, the fourth gowned figure flies right and twists to face away. Her arms are extended horizontally. With her right hand, she appears to reach for or drop small objects, perhaps blossoms(?). Her left hand is extended near the basket carried by the figure at the left.

The lowest figure at left in the topmost group of figures holds a (wicker?) basket, which may contain flowers(?), on top of her head. A similar basket is held on the head of a small figure further to the right.

The lowest figure at left in the topmost group of figures holds a basket, which may contain flowers(?), on top of her head. Additional small circular objects that may be blossoms(?) are visible in a horizontal line in the middle of the circle of figures upper left.

The final group of four smaller figures who form a circle in the upper left portion of the composition fly or hover atop a ring of clouds that connects with the larger plume of clouds on the right side of the picture.
Visible against each side margin near the top of the composition, two piers with vaguely Corinthian capitals support (what is likely) a pointed arch, though the arch itself is obscured.
Beams of light extend outward from the upper middle of the composition, often terminating in dark, spiky points that form concentric bands, particularly on the left side of the design.
